'''Suzi Gablik''' (born 1934) in New York, New York, is an American artist, a prolific and influential [[visionary]] author and art critic, and a professor of art history and art criticism.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suzi Gablik - Dictionary of Art Historians|url=http://arthistorians.info/gabliks|website=arthistorians.info|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref> She lives in [[Blacksburg, Virginia]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Resurgence • Author Suzi Gablik|url=http://www.resurgence.org/magazine/author10-Suzi-Gablik.html|website=www.resurgence.org|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref> and lived in London for almost twenty years.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suzi Gablik|url=https://americanart.si.edu/artist/suzi-gablik-1707|website=Smithsonian American Art Museum|accessdate=29 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> A prevailing theme for Gablik, enunciated in ''Has Modernism Failed?'' and quoted in the [[Kirkus Reviews]] article about her book, ''The Reenchantment of Art'', states, "Since [[the enlightenment]] ... our view of what is real has been organized around the [[hegemony]] of a technical and [[materialist]] world view ... we no longer have any sense of having a [[soul]]."<ref name="Reenchantment Kirkus">{{cite web|title= The Reenchantment of Art by Suzi Gablik {{!}} Kirkus Reviews|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/suzi-gablik/the-reenchantment-of-art/|accessdate=4 September 2016|language=en-us}}</ref>
==Education and art training== In 1951, after a summer studying at [[Black Mountain College]], she entered [[Hunter College]] where she studied with [[Robert Motherwell]] and received her BA in 1955.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suzi Gablik - Artist, Fine Art Prices, Auction Records for Suzi Gablik|url=http://askart.com/artist/Suzi_Gablik/101594/Suzi_Gablik.aspx|website=askart.com|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref> After working primarily as a painter, she had her first solo show in 1966. Later, she turned her attention to [[collage]].
==Work as art critic== Gablik has written articles for ''[[Art in America]]'' (for which she was the London correspondent for fifteen years),<ref>{{cite web|last1=Art|first1=Archives of American|title=Detailed description of the Suzi Gablik papers, 1954-2014 {{!}} Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution|url=http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/suzi-gablik-papers-16176/more|website=www.aaa.si.edu|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref> [[Art News|''ARTnews'']] (1962-1966),<ref>{{cite web|last1=Art|first1=Archives of American|title=Detailed description of the Suzi Gablik papers, 1954-2014 {{!}} Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution|url=http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/suzi-gablik-papers-16176/more|website=www.aaa.si.edu|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref> ''[[Times Literary Supplement]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Suzi Gablik|url=https://www.overdrive.com/creators/85666/suzi-gablik|website=OverDrive|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gablik|first1=Suzi|title=A Catalogue of Horrors: Suzi Gablik on Edward Kienholz, in 1965 {{!}} ARTnews|url=http://www.artnews.com/2016/08/26/a-catalogue-of-horrors-suzi-gablik-on-edward-kienholz-in-1965/|accessdate=3 September 2016|work=www.artnews.com}}</ref> and ''[[The New Criterion]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Gablik - Art and God|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/55986391/Gablik-Art-and-God|website=Scribd|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref> as well as for blogs.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gablik|first1=Suzi|title=Suzi Gablik|url=http://moncon.greenmuseum.org/papers/gablik.pdf|website=GreenMuseum|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref> Chapters 2 and 5 (the final chapter) of her book ''Has Modernism Failed?'' ([[Thames & Hudson]], 1982)<ref>{{cite web|title=Aesthetics -|url=http://www.rowan.edu/open/philosop/clowney/Aesthetics/scans/Gablik/Gablikb.htm|website=www.rowan.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Gablik|first1=Suzi|title=Aesthetics -Chap.2:Individualism:Art for Art's Sake, or Art for Society's Sake?|url=http://www.rowan.edu/open/philosop/clowney/Aesthetics/scans/Gablik/Gablika.htm|website=www.rowan.edu|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref> are part of an online study guide about [[aesthetics]]. In her article "Deconstructing aesthetics: Toward a responsible art," which appeared in the ''[[New Art Examiner]]'', she contended that "The national framework of aesthetics—which has favored an ontology of objectification, permanence, and egocentricity—has hardened into a presumption that is conserving and reinforcing a reluctance to make art which is inherently communicative and compassionately responsive."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gablk|first1=Suzi|title=Deconstructing aesthetics:Toward a responsible art|publisher=New Art Examiner|date=January 1989|pages=32–35}}</ref>
==Author== Gablik's first book was ''Pop Art Redefined'', co-authored with art critic [[John Russell (art critic)|John Russell]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Art|first1=Archives of American|title=Detailed description of the Suzi Gablik papers, 1954-2014 {{!}} Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution|url=http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/suzi-gablik-papers-16176/more|website=www.aaa.si.edu|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref> Her other books include: ''Has Modernism Failed?'' (1982),<ref>{{cite web|title=Has Modernism Failed? by Suzi Gablik|url=https://www.lensculture.com/books/1147-has-modernism-failed|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref> ''The Reenchantment of Art'' (1992),<ref name="Reenchantment Kirkus" /> ''Conversations Before the End of Time'' (1995),<ref name="Conversations">Gablik, Suzi. [https://www.amazon.com/Conversations-Before-Time-Suzi-Gablik/dp/0500278385 ''Conversations Before the End of Time''], New York: Thames & Hudson, 1995.</ref> ''Living the Magical Life: An Oracle Adventure'' (2002),<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gablik|first1=Suzi|title=Living the magical life : an oracular adventure|date=2002|publisher=Phanes Press|location=Grand Rapids, MI|isbn=978-1890482862}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Living the Magical Life {{!}} Library|url=http://library.noetic.org/library/publication-books/living-magical-life|website=library.noetic.org|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Artist Suzi Gablik|url=http://www.askart.com/artist/Suzi_Gablik/101594/Suzi_Gablik.aspx|website=AskArt|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref> and ''Magritte'' (1970), about the Belgian [[surrealist]] [[René Magritte]], written while living with the Magrittes.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gablik|first1=Suzi|title=Magritte|publisher=New York Graphic Society|isbn=0500490031|url=http://0-www.worldcat.org.novacat.nova.edu/title/magritte/oclc/109514|language=English}}</ref>
Gablik’s ''The Reenchantment of Art'' announced her disenchantment with “the compulsive and oppressive consumeristic framework in which we do our work,” and argued that a re-connection to the primordial and to ritual might allow “for a return of soul.”<ref name="Reenchantment">Gablik, Suzi. [https://www.amazon.com/Reenchantment-Art-Suzi-Gablik/dp/0500276897 ''The Reenchantment of Art''.] London: Thames and Hudson, 1992, p. 3, 11. {{ISBN|978-0-5002768-9-1}}. Retrieved February 22, 2018.</ref><ref name="Morgan">Morgan, David. “Enchantment, Disenchantment, Re-Enchantment,” in [https://www.routledge.com/Re-Enchantment/Elkins-Morgan/p/book/9780203891667 ''Re-Enchantment'', edited by James Elkins, David Morgan.] New York: Routledge, 2009, p. 16-17. Retrieved February 22, 2018.</ref> Instead of traditional forms of religion, however, Gablik sought out contemporary art that she believed broke out of the Western framework, championing the work of artists such as [[Frank Gohlke]], [[Gilah Yelin Hirsch]], [[Nancy Holt]], Dominique Mazeaud, [[Fern Shaffer]] and Otello Anderson, [[Starhawk]], [[James Turrell]] and [[Mierle Laderman Ukeles]], in the book and in subsequent critical writing.<ref name="Orion">Gablik, Suzi. “Arts and the Earth: Making Art as If the World Mattered,” ''Orion'', Autumn 1995, p. 44.</ref>
In addition to her critical articles, Gablik has conducted interviews with other artists, art critics or philosophers, such as [[Richard Shusterman]].<ref>{{cite web|title=FAU - Breaking Out of the White Cube|url=http://www.fau.edu/humanitieschair/white-cube.php|website=www.fau.edu|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="Shaffer Anderson">Gablik, Suzi. “The Ecological Imperative, An Interview with [[Fern Shaffer]] and Othello Anderson,” ''Art Papers'', Nov. 1991.</ref> She has also written essays for exhibition catalogues of shows that she has curated.<ref>{{cite web|title=apexart :: Suzi Gablik :: Sacred Wild|url=http://www.apexart.org/exhibitions/gablik.htm|website=www.apexart.org|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref>
==Teaching== Gablik taught at [[Virginia Commonwealth University's School of the Arts]] and [[Washington and Lee University]], and has lectured at many others. Between 1976–1979, she participated in [[International Communications Agency|US International Communications Agency]] lecture tours in India, Hungary, Pakistan, and countries of South Asia.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Art|first1=Archives of American|title=Detailed description of the Suzi Gablik papers, 1954-2014 {{!}} Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution|url=http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/suzi-gablik-papers-16176/more|website=www.aaa.si.edu|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref> She participated in a March 7, 2013 [[podcast]] on the subject of "[[Solastalgia]] and Creative Response" with Angelo Manno and [[Glenn Albrecht]].<ref>https://www.bing.com/search?q=living+hero+suzi+gablik+podcast&form=EDGHPC&qs=PF&cvid=80218b9327c24ea5a23e8d880e59b9b7&pq=living+hero+suzi+gablik+podcast </ref> She also gave a presentation at the Fall 1986 Mountain Lake Symposium on "Postmodernism and the Question of Meaning: For a New Spiritualism."<ref>{{cite web|title=Postmodernism and the Question of Meaning|url=https://msu.edu/course/ha/452/gablikpostmodernism.htm|website=msu.edu|accessdate=7 September 2016}}</ref>
==Biography== Gablik was born to Anthony J. Gablik and Geraldine Schwarz Gablik in New York, New York in 1934. She "hung out with Jasper Johns"<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview with Suzi Gablik|url=http://jari.podbean.com/2009/11/01/interview-with-suzi-gablik/|website=jari.podbean.com|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref> and was an acquaintance of [[John Cage]], [[Ad Reinhardt]], [[Ray Johnson]], and [[Robert Rauschenberg]]. In 2014, she donated a collection of her papers, lectures, notes, and other files to the [[Smithsonian Archives of American Art]].<ref>Suzi Gablik papers, 1954-2014. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. </ref>

{{advert|date=December 2013}} {{infobox organization | name = Third Way | logo = Thirdwaylogo.png | alt = Logo of Third Way | founded = {{start date and age|2005}} | founders = Jonathan Cowan
Matt Bennett
Nancy Hale
Jim Kessler | tax_id = 20-1734070{{cite web|url=https://www.guidestar.org/FinDocuments/2016/201/734/2016-201734070-0e305cb0-9O.pdf|title=Form 990: Return of Organization Exempt from Income Tax|format=PDF|publisher=Third Way|date=December 31, 2016|accessdate=November 10, 2018}} | status = [[501(c)(4)]] | headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|38.903358|-77.039347|display=inline, title}} | leader_name = Jonathan Cowan{{cite web|url=https://www.thirdway.org/about|title=About|publisher=Third Way|accessdate=November 10, 2018}} | leader_title = [[President (corporation)|President]] | leader_name2 = John L. Vogelstein | leader_title2 = [[Chairman]], [[Board of Trustees]] | subsidiaries = Third Way Institute | revenue = $10,405,228 | revenue_year = 2016 | expenses = $8,704,498 | expenses_year = 2016 | employees = 71 | employees_year = 2016 | volunteers = 32 | volunteers_year = 2016 | website = {{url|thirdway.org}} }} {{New Democrats|expanded=none}} '''Third Way''' is a [[Washington, D.C.]]–based [[public policy]] [[think tank]] founded in 2005.{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/political-groups-compete-to-represent-the-center/|work=The New York Times|first=Michael D.|last=Shear|title=Political Groups Compete to Represent the Center|date=February 9, 2011|accessdate=November 9, 2014}} The think tank develops political and policy ideas, conducts [[public opinion]] research and hosts an array of public events, issues briefings, etc. The organization has four policy divisions: Economics, [[National Security]], Clean Energy and Social Policy & Politics. Third Way develops and advocates for policies that it says represent the "modern [[center-left]] ideas".{{cite web |title=Third Way - About Us|url=http://www.third-way.com/about_us|accessdate=November 9, 2014}} Third Way was honored as 2013 North American Think Tank of the Year by ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'', a British monthly current affairs magazine, for its "original, influential, and rigorous work on the most pressing challenges facing people, governments, and businesses".{{cite web|title=The 50 Most Influential Think Tanks in the United States|url=https://thebestschools.org/features/most-influential-think-tanks/|website=The Best Schools|date=2013|accessdate=March 14, 2018}} The think tank's supporters and advocates include Democratic politicians, other center-left think tanks and individual donors.{{cite web|last1=James|first1=Hohmann|title=Third Way picks up 3 new Senate co-chairs|url=https://www.politico.com/blogs/on-congress/2011/02/third-way-picks-up-3-new-senate-co-chairs-033371|website=Politico|date=February 15, 2011|accessdate=November 10, 2018}} Third Way's funding also partially comes from philanthropies, foundations and personal donations. In the past decade, Third Way has been directly involved in policy issues such as the benefits of energy innovation, student accountability measures under the [[Every Student Succeeds Act]], deficit reduction, proposals to reform [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] and [[Medicaid]], the repeal of "[[Don't ask, don't tell]]" and new trade accords with Korea, Colombia and Panama. == History == Third Way grew out of the nonprofit group Americans for Gun Safety (AGS), which was formed in 2000 with the goal of resetting the gun control movement and advancing gun safety laws by using moderate ideas that appealed to both sides of the debate.{{cite web|last1=Ball|first1=Molly|title=How the Gun-Control Movement Got Smart|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2013/02/how-the-gun-control-movement-got-smart/272934/|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=7 February 2013}} AGS' primary political project was around closing the gun show loophole in the [[Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act]], through which people could purchase guns at gun shows without needing a background check. It helped pass two 2000 state-level ballot initiatives in Colorado and Oregon to close the gun show loophole there and championed federal legislation carried by Senators [[John McCain]] (R-AZ) and [[Joe Lieberman]] (D-CT), which failed to pass. AGS was folded into Third Way in 2005 in the wake of the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential election]] as a policy, messaging and strategy idea center and think tank. Third Way was cofounded by Jonathan Cowan, Matt Bennett,{{cite web |last= Bennett |first=Matt |title=Matt Bennett, Senior Vice President for Public Affairs|url=http://www.thirdway.org/about/leadership/matt-bennett|website=Third Way Staff|publisher=Third Way|accessdate=November 9, 2014}} Jim Kessler{{cite web|last=Kessler|first=Jim|title=Jim Kessler, Senior Vice President for Policy |url=http://www.thirdway.org/about/leadership/jim-kessler|publisher=Third Way|accessdate=November 9, 2014}} and Nancy Hale.{{cite web|last=Hale|first=Nancy|title=Nancy Hale, Senior Vice President for Strategy & Leadership Development|url=http://www.thirdway.org/about/leadership/nancy-hale|publisher=Third Way|accessdate=November 9, 2014}} == Areas of interest == Third Way has four major policy programs. The Economic Program focuses on helping the American middle class succeed in the midst of growing global competition.{{cite web|last=Gerwin |first=Ed |url=http://www.third-way.com/programs/economic_program |title=Programs - Economic Program |publisher= Third Way |date= |accessdate=2014-11-09}} The National Security Program focuses on issues of security, foreign policy, surveillance and technology, public opinion and the United States military.{{cite web |last=Way |first=Third |url=http://www.third-way.com/programs/national_security_program |title=Programs - National Security Program |publisher=Third Way |date= |accessdate=2014-11-09}} Third Way has also houses a [[clean energy]] program that promotes a range of zero-emissions technologies, like carbon capture and advanced nuclear reactors as well as [[renewable energy]], all in an effort to address the [[climate crisis]].{{cite web|last=McCraw |first=Kimble |url=http://www.third-way.com/programs/clean_energy_program |title=Programs - Clean Energy Program |publisher=Third Way |date= |accessdate=2014-11-09}} Finally, it has a Social Policy and Politics Program to advocate for change on progressive issues including marriage equality, education, marijuana, immigration and gun control.{{cite web|url=http://www.third-way.com/programs/social_policy_and_politics_program|title=Social Policy and Politics Program|publisher=Third Way|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141123121352/http://www.third-way.com/programs/social_policy_and_politics_program|archivedate=November 23, 2014|deadurl=yes}} == Policy work == In 2010, Third Way sponsored a report written by [[William Galston]] of the [[Brookings Institution]] and Elaine Kamarck{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/arena/bio/elaine_c_kamarck.html |title=The Arena: - Elaine C. Kamarck Bio |publisher=Politico.com |date=2010-10-21 |accessdate=2012-11-07}} of [[Harvard University]]'s [[Kennedy School of Government|Kennedy School]] entitled ''Change You Can Believe In Needs a Government You Can Trust''.{{cite web|url=http://content.thirdway.org/publications/133/Third_Way_Report_-_Trust_in_Government.pdf |title=Change You Can Believe In Needs a Government You Can Trust |publisher=Thirdway.org |date= |accessdate=2014-11-09}} The report analyzed Americans' trust in government and reported it was in serious decline and could present significant challenges to the [[Obama administration]]'s agenda. Third Way's other economic work has included rural reinvestment efforts, a plan to make opportunity more widely available to American middle class and defending the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]]. As an example of Third Way's rural reinvestment program, Third Way developed the policies framed in Spurring Weatherization Investments in Rural America, which was introduced by Representative [[Jim Clyburn]] (D-South Carolina) and Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] (R-South Carolina) as the Rural Energy Savings Program.{{cite web|url=http://merkley.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/?id=69edc678-591d-449c-af2c-fba66ba1bc91 |title=Jeff Merkley - Fighting for Oregon in the U.S. Senate: Home |publisher=Merkley.senate.gov |date=2010-03-10 |accessdate=2012-11-07}} Third Way argued for members of opposing parties to sit together at the President's annual address in 2011 and 2012.{{cite news|last=McDuffee|first=Allen|title=State of the Union: Will Republicans and Democrats sit together?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/think-tanked/post/state-of-the-union-will-republicans-and-democrats-sit-together/2012/01/23/gIQADiZTLQ_blog.html|accessdate=March 20, 2012|newspaper=Washington Post|date=January 23, 2012}} Third Way has recently worked on a campaign to evaluate the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] connection with voters after the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]].{{cite web|last1=Karni|first1=Annie|title=Democratic Party rethink gets $20 million injection|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/democratic-party-voters-reconnect-233666|website=Politico|accessdate=17 January 2017}} Along those lines, Third Way hosted consultations and meetings with politicians and strategists from around the country to develop a Democratic strategy for winning [[United States elections, 2018|2018]] and [[United States elections, 2020|2020 elections]].{{cite web|title=The Democratic Dilemma|url=https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21726088-whatever-happens-white-house-democratic-party-faces-fundamental-choice|website=The Economist|accessdate=10 August 2017}} As of 2017, Third Way's economic program is undertaking a campaign to highlight the scarcity of opportunity as a root cause of [[income inequality]]. In March 2018, Third Way released a report outlining a new cause for the Democratic Party and several policy ideas that the organization says "redefines government's role in expanding the opportunity to earn".{{cite web|title=A New Generation of Ideas: A Social Contract for the Digital Age|url=https://www.thirdway.org/memo/a-new-generation-of-ideas-a-social-contract-for-the-digital-age|website=Third Way|accessdate=20 March 2018}} ''The Washington Post'''s coverage of the report considered it "an opening bid in the 2020 'ideas primary'".{{cite web|last1=James|first1=Hohmann|title=The Daily 202: Third Way makes an opening bid in the 2020 'ideas primary'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/daily-202/2018/03/15/daily-202-third-way-makes-an-opening-bid-in-the-2020-ideas-primary/5aa9df8730fb047655a06cb1/|website=Washington Post|accessdate=15 March 2018}} Other parts of Third Way's work are also related to politics. The organization has studied the [[Swing state|battleground states and districts]] that will determine congressional majorities in 2018.{{cite web|last1=Hohmann|first1=James|title=The Daily 202: Even sweeping the suburbs would not be enough for Democrats to win the House majority|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/daily-202/2017/06/29/daily-202-even-sweeping-the-suburbs-would-not-be-enough-for-democrats-to-win-the-house-majority/59540e75e9b69b7071abc93e/|website=The Washington Post|accessdate=29 June 2017}} For example, their public opinion research and focus groups revealed that persuadable voters who backed [[Barack Obama]] and then [[Donald Trump]] saw Trump as focused on creating jobs and Democrats as "working for someone else".{{cite web|last1=Debenedetti|first1=Gabriel|title=Third Way study warns Democrats: Avoid far-left populism|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/05/third-way-democrats-jobs-party-242308|website=Politico|accessdate=5 September 2017}} In its report on the findings, Third Way called for the Democratic Party to focus on becoming the Jobs Party to voters. == Specific topics == Third Way has worked on the following policy issues: # The economic benefits of [[green energy]]. Since 2010, Third Way is [[lobbying]] the creation of an alternative clean energy and climate agenda. Part of this effort has included highlighting and advocating the work of advanced nuclear technology start-ups.{{cite web|last1=Plumer|first1=Brad|title=Nuclear power is dying. Can radical innovation save it?|url=https://www.vox.com/energy-and-environment/2017/3/27/15043522/nuclear-power-future-innovation|website=Vox|accessdate=27 March 2017}} The organization has recently partnered with the Department of Energy's Gateway for Accelerated Innovation in Nuclear (GAIN) to connect advanced nuclear developers with federal laboratories.{{cite web|last1=Yurman|first1=Dan|title=Advanced Nuclear Designs Imagined in Third Way Exhibit|url=http://www.theenergycollective.com/dan-yurman/2415993/advanced-nuclear-designs-imagined-third-way-exhibit|website=The Energy Collective}} # Marriage equality. Third Way launched the Commitment Campaign in 2011 with the aim of finding common ground between the [[LGBT]] and [[religious community]] that culminated in reframing the [[marriage equality]] debate to focus on "love and commitment" instead of "rights and benefits".{{cite web|last1=Madhani|first1=Aamer|title=Bipartisan group reframes case for legalizing gay marriage|url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2011-11-06/gay-marriage-commitment-campaign/51098348/1|website=USA Today}} The group also worked on the repeal of "[[Don't ask, don't tell]]" and the [[Defense of Marriage Act]]. # Trade agreements. Third Way advocated for new trade accords with Korea, Colombia and Panama and advocated for the [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]]. # Gun safety. Third Way has continued to work on similar issues to those addressed by Americans for Gun Safety, which include universal background checks.{{cite web|last1=Ball|first1=Molly|title=How the Gun-Control Movement Got Smart|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2013/02/how-the-gun-control-movement-got-smart/272934/|website=The Atlantic}} == Criticism == === Invalid research === In 2017, the Third Way think tank conducted a listening tour in rural Wisconsin as part of a political research effort to understand the results of the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/10/on-safari-in-trumps-america/543288/|title=On Safari in Trump's America|last=Ball|first=Molly|date=3 October 2017|website=The Atlantic|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228112341/https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/10/on-safari-in-trumps-america/543288/|archive-date=28 February 2018|dead-url=|access-date=5 March 2018}} This tour was the feature of an article in ''[[The Atlantic]]'' magazine, where reporter Molly Ball observed many focus group participants expressing strongly politically partisan views that challenged Third Way's ideology that political partisanship was not most people’s primary concern. Ball recounts hearing focus group participants blame things like government bureaucracy, changes in society and the family, young people, welfare recipients, Muslims, Republicans, Democrats, income inequality, gerrymandering and union rights for their problems. Despite this, Ball writes that Third Way summarized its findings in a short report that ignored all the sentiments heard on the tour which challenged Third Way's ideology and instead selectively highlighted sentiments which adhered to Third Way's ideology: {{quote|text=The report surprised me when I read it. Despite the great variety of views the researchers and I had heard on our tour, the report had somehow reached the conclusion that Wisconsinites wanted consensus, moderation, and pragmatism—just like Third Way. We had heard people blame each other for their own difficulties, take refuge in tribalism, and appeal to extremes. But the report mentioned little of that. Instead it described the prevailing attitude as "an intense work ethic that binds the community together and helps it adapt to change.{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/10/on-safari-in-trumps-america/543288/|title=On Safari in Trump's America|last=Ball|first=Molly|website=The Atlantic|date=23 October 2017|accessdate=10 November 2018}}|sign=Molly Ball}} As a result of Ball's account, the validity of Third Way's research has come into question.{{Cite web|url=https://washingtonmonthly.com/2017/10/28/are-third-ways-focus-groups-valid-research/|title=Are Third Way's Focus Groups Valid Research?|last=Atkins|first=David|date=28 October 2017|website=Washington Monthly|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} However, Third Way strongly disputed Ball's claim in a public post. Third Way's Matt Bennett wrote in response: "We are dismayed that in the story, Molly writes that we omitted information that is actually in the report{{cite web|author1=Nancy Hale and Luke Watson|title=Wisconsin District Visit|url=http://www.thirdway.org/report/wisconsin-district-visit|website=Third Way|accessdate=16 September 2017}} we drafted about the WI visit. And she indicates that we have drawn conclusions that we do not reach and do not share".{{cite web|last1=Bennett|first1=Matt|title=What The Atlantic Gets Wrong about Third Way|url=https://medium.com/third-way/what-the-atlantic-gets-wrong-about-third-way-53ce970ecb3c|website=Medium}} He also stated: :Yes, in the last page of the report, we provide some evidence that people believe they can still work together. But nowhere in the report do we even imply that means they think politicians should support a centrist policy agenda. [...] Moreover, this research is by its very nature anecdotal. It is about impressions, which can vary widely, not quantitative data, which can be extrapolated. We make that very clear in our description of the project and in each of the reports on the visits we’ve done, each of which have been quite different from the rest.{{cite web|last1=Bennett|first1=Matt|title=What The Atlantic Gets Wrong about Third Way|url=https://medium.com/third-way/what-the-atlantic-gets-wrong-about-third-way-53ce970ecb3c|website=Medium|accessdate=2017-10-23}} === Special interests === The majority of the think tank's funding comes from individuals with close ties to the banking industry and its board of trustees consists mostly of investment bankers. Political commentator [[David Sirota]] suggested that the think tank's initiatives to combat [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] expansion despite popular sentiment is because it would cause trustees of the think tank to pay higher taxes.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/third-way-majority-our-financial-support-wall-street-business-executives/|title=Third Way: 'Majority of Our Financial Support' From Wall Street, Business Executives|last=Fang|first=Lee|date=11 December 2013|website=The Nation|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 March 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://pando.com/2013/12/11/disruption-vs-intransigence-a-tale-of-two-political-parties/|title=Disruption vs Intransigence: A tale of two political parties|last=Sirota|first=David|date=11 December 2013|website=PandoDaily|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Hunter of [[Daily Kos]] has suggested Third Way's ties to the banking industry is the reason for its opposition to Senator [[Elizabeth Warren|Elizabeth Warren's]] platform of Wall Street reform.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2013/12/03/1259899/-Why-the-Third-Way-hates-Sen-Elizabeth-nbsp-Warren#|title=Why the Third Way hates Sen. Elizabeth Warren|last=Hunter|first=|date=4 December 2013|website=Daily Kos|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Investigative journalist [[Lee Fang]] of [[The Nation]] alleges the think tank's ties to the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] are "tenuous" and that it exists to serve as a vehicle for [[corporate]] and [[right-wing]] interests to shape the economic policies of the party.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/gop-donors-and-k-street-fuel-third-ways-advice-democratic-party/|title=GOP Donors and K Street Fuel Third Way's Advice for the Democratic Party|last=Fang|first=Lee|date=|website=The Nation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == See also == {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Centrism]] * [[Democratic Leadership Council]] * [[New Democrat Network]] * [[New Labour]] * [[Third Way (centrism)]] {{colend}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.thirdway.org/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Third Way (Think Tank)}} [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Political and economic think tanks in the United States]] [[Category:Politics of the United States]] [[Category:Think tanks established in 2005]]

{{for|underground rock band|Tragic Mulatto}} The '''tragic mulatto''' is a stereotypical [[fictional character]] that appeared in [[American literature]] during the 19th and 20th centuries, from the 1840s.<ref name=Fer/> The "tragic mulatto" is an archetypical [[mixed race|mixed-race]] person (a "[[mulatto]]"), who is assumed to be [[depression (mood)|sad]], or even [[suicide|suicidal]], because they fail to completely fit in the "white world" or the "black world".<ref name=Fer/> As such, the "tragic mulatto" is depicted as the victim of the society in society divided by race, where there is no place for one who is neither completely "black" nor "white". This trope was also used by abolitionists in order to create a mixed-race, but white-appearing, slave that would serve as a tool to express sentimentality to white readers in an effort to paint slaves as "more human".<ref name=Robinson>Cedric J. Robinson, Forgeries of Memory and Meaning: Blacks and the Regimes of Race in American Theater and Film Before World War II</ref>
The related concept of the "tragic half-breed" or "tragic [[mestizo]]" involves the child of a white person and a Native American. Especially when such a person has a white mother and native father (and is thus excluded under most native tribes' [[matrilineal kinship]] from being considered legally native), the same basic tropes of dual societal rejection apply. {{TOC limit|2}}
==Tragic mulatta==
The female "tragic [[octoroon]]" was a [[stock character]] of abolitionist literature: a light-skinned woman raised as if a white woman in her father's household, until his [[bankruptcy]] or death has her reduced to a menial position and sold.<ref>Ariela J. Gross, ''What Blood Won't Tell: A History of Race on Trial in America'', p. 61. {{ISBN|978-0-674-03130-2}}</ref> She may even be unaware of her status before being so reduced.<ref name="davis">Kathy Davis. "[http://www.facstaff.bucknell.edu/gcarr/19cusww/lb/HNQSPH.html Headnote to Lydia Maria Child's 'The Quadroons' and 'Slavery's Pleasant Homes'.]"</ref> This character allowed abolitionists to draw attention to the sexual exploitation in slavery, and unlike the suffering of the field hands, did not allow slaveholders to retort that the sufferings of Northern mill hands were no easier, since the Northern mill owner would not sell his own children into slavery.<ref>Werner Sollors, ''Interracialism'' p. 285 {{ISBN|0-19-512856-7}}</ref>
The "tragic mulatta" figure is a woman of biracial heritage who endures the hardships of [[African-American]]s in the [[Antebellum era|antebellum]] [[Southern United States|South]], even though she may look white enough that her ethnicity is not immediately obvious. As the name implies, tragic mulattas almost always meet a bad end. [[Lydia Maria Child]]'s 1842 [[short story]] "The [[Quadroon]]s" is generally credited as the first work of literature to feature a tragic mulatta,<ref name=Fer/> to garner support for emancipation and equal rights. Child followed up "The Quadroons" with the 1843 short story "Slavery's Pleasant Homes", which also has a tragic mulatta character.<ref name=Fer/>
Writer [[Eva Allegra Raimon]] notes that Child "allowed white readers to identify with the victim by gender while distancing themselves by race and thus to avoid confronting a racial ideology that denies the full humanity of nonwhite women." The [[passing (sociology)|passing]] character, Clare Kendry, in [[Nella Larsen]]'s ''[[Passing (novel)|Passing]]'' has been deemed a "tragic mulatta".<ref name=Fer/>
Generally, the tragic mulatta archetype falls into one of three categories:
* A woman who can [[Passing (racial identity)|"pass"]] for white attempts to do so, is accepted as white by society and falls in love with a white man. Eventually, her status as a bi-racial person is revealed and the story ends in tragedy. * A woman who appears to be white and thus passes as being so. It is believed that she is of [[Greeks|Greek]] or [[Spain|Spanish]] descent. She has suffered little hardship in her life, but upon the revelation that she is mixed race, she loses her social standing. * A woman who has all the social graces that come along with being a [[middle-class]] or [[upper-class]] white woman is nonetheless subjected to [[slavery]].
A common objection to this character is that she allows readers to pity the plight of oppressed or enslaved races, but only through a veil of whiteness — that is, instead of sympathizing with a true racial "other", one is sympathizing with a character who is made as much like one's own race as possible. The "tragic mulatta" often appeared in [[novels]] intended for women, also, and some of the character's appeal lay in the lurid fantasy of a person just like them suddenly cast into a lower social class after the discovery of a small amount of "black blood" that renders her unfit for proper marriage.
==In popular culture== {{Refimprove section|date=January 2016}} ===Literature featuring "tragic mulatto" and "tragic mulatta" characters in pivotal roles=== *''[[Le Mulâtre]]'' 1837 (French) *[[Sab (novel)|''Sab'']] by Gertrudis Gomez de Avellaneda, 1841. *"The Quadroons", 1842 short story by Lydia Maria Child (introduced the literary character of the tragic mulatto)<ref name=Fer/> *"Slavery's Pleasant Homes", 1843 short story by Lydia Maria Child<ref name=Fer/> *''[[Uncle Tom's Cabin|Uncle Tom's Cabin; or, Life Among the Lowly]]''), 1852 novel by Harriet Beecher Stowe (published serially 1851–1852)<ref name=Robinson/> *''[[Clotel|Clotel; or, The President's Daughter]]'', 1853 novel by [[William Wells Brown]]<ref name=Fer/> *''The Garies and Their Friends'', 1857 novel by [[Frank J. Webb]] *''[[The Octoroon]] (Life in Louisiana)'' 1859 play, by Dion Bocicault<ref name=Robinson/> * ''[[A Escrava Isaura (novel)|A Escrava Isaura]]'', 1875 novel by Brazilian author [[Bernardo Guimarães]] * ''[[Iola Leroy]]'', 1892 novel by [[Frances Harper]] *[[Désirée’s Baby|''Désirée's Baby'']], 1893 short story by [[Kate Chopin]] *''[[The Wife of His Youth and Other Stories of the Color-Line]]'' by [[Charles W. Chesnutt]] (1899) *''[[The House Behind the Cedars]]'', 1900 novel by Charles W. Chesnutt *''[[The Marrow of Tradition]]'', 1901 novel by Charles W. Chesnutt *''[[The Clansman]]'', 1905 novel by [[Thomas Dixon, Jr.]]<ref name=Fer/> (the source material for D. W. Griffith's ''[[The Birth of a Nation]]''). *[[Summer (novel)|''Summer'']], novel by [[Edith Wharton]] published in 1917 *"Cross", poem by [[Langston Hughes]] published 1925 *''[[Show Boat (novel)|Show Boat]]'', 1926 novel by [[Edna Ferber]] (also the source material for the [[Show Boat|1927 stage musical]]). *"Mulatto", poem by Langston Hughes published 1927 *''The White Girl'', 1929 novel by Vara Caspary<ref name=Fer/> *''[[Passing (novel)|Passing]]'', 1929 novel by [[Nella Larsen]]<ref name=Fer/> *''[[Dark Lustre]]'', 1932 novel by Geoffrey Barnes<ref name=Fer/> *''[[Light in August]]'', 1932 novel by [[William Faulkner]] *''[[Imitation of Life (novel)|Imitation of Life]]'', 1933 novel by [[Fannie Hurst]] *"Father and Son", short story by Langston Hughes published 1934 *''[[Mulatto (play)|Mulatto: A Play of the Deep South]]'', 1935 play by Langston Hughes *''[[Their Eyes Were Watching God]]'', 1937 novel by [[Zora Neale Hurston]] *''Lost Boundaries'', 1940 book by William L. White<ref name=Fer/> *''The Wind From Nowhere'', 1943 novel by [[Oscar Micheaux]] *''The Barrier'', 1950 opera by Langston Hughes and [[Jan Meyerowitz]] *"African Morning", 1952 short story by Langston Hughes *''[[Band of Angels]]'', 1955 novel by [[Robert Penn Warren]] *''[[To Kill a Mockingbird]]'', 1960 novel by [[Harper Lee]] *''[[A Soldier's Play]]'', 1981 play by Charles Fuller *''[[Devil in a Blue Dress]]'', 1990 novel by [[Walter Mosely]] *''[[The Human Stain]]'', 2000 novel by [[Philip Roth]]

''I Crossed the Color Line'' *''[[Purple Rain (film)|Purple Rain]]'' (1984) *''[[A Soldier's Story]]'' (1984) *''[[Devil in a Blue Dress (film)|Devil in a Blue Dress]]'' (1995) *''[[The Human Stain (film)|The Human Stain]]'' (2003)
=== Television movies and series featuring "tragic mulatta" characters in pivotal roles === * ''[[Alex Haley's Queen]]'', the acclaimed television series by Alex Haley, offers a subversion of the "tragic mulatta" archetype, while making reference to many of its elements. * ''[[A Escrava Isaura (novel)|A Escrava Isaura]]'' has been adapted to Brazilian television twice, first in 1976 (as ''[[Escrava Isaura (1976 TV series)|Escrava Isaura]]''), and [[A Escrava Isaura (2004 TV series)|again in 2004]]. * ''[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]]'' (the television series) featured a tragic mulatta character (portrayed by [[Melissa Marsala]]) in its 2000 episode "[[Are You Now or Have You Ever Been]]". * ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' and ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' character [[Worf]]. Orphaned at the age of 5, [[Worf]], a [[Klingon]], was adopted and raised by [[human]] parents along with a human brother, Nikolai. Throughout both series franchises, [[Worf]] frequently struggles with his identity. Additionally, Worf's son, Alexander Rozhenko, is {{frac|3|4}} Klingon and {{frac|1|4}} human, largely raised by Worf's human parents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mauricebroaddus.com/uncategorized/worfs-journey-of-blackness-part-i/|title=Worf's Journey of Blackness Part I|author=Maurice Broaddus|date=March 23, 2009|work=mauricebroaddus.com}}</ref> * ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' character [[List of recurring Star Trek: Deep Space Nine characters#Tora Ziyal|Tora Ziyal]]. She is the daughter of Cardassian [[Dukat (Star Trek)|Gul Dukat]] and his Bajoran mistress, Tora Naprem. Ziyal is portrayed as caught between [[Cardassian]] and [[Bajoran]] cultures and belonging in neither. She briefly finds a home on [[Deep Space Nine (fictional space station)|Deep Space Nine]] until she dies tragically at the hands of Gul Dukat's second in command, [[List of recurring Star Trek: Deep Space Nine characters#Damar|Damar]]. As a recurring character, Ziyal plays a pivotal role in the story arc of the series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.startrek.com/database_article/ziyal|title=Ziyal, Tora|website=StarTrek.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-07}}</ref> *''[[Star Trek]]'' character [[Spock]] is half-[[human]], half-[[Vulcan (Star Trek)|Vulcan]]. *''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'' character [[B'Elanna Torres]] also is often tormented by her existence as a [[Human]]/[[Klingon]] [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrid]]. *In ''[[Power Rangers Mystic Force]]'', the Troblin (half Troll, half Goblin) Phineas is despised by both Trolls and Goblins.<ref>{{cite web|title=Half-Breed Discrimination|work=TvTropes|url=http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfBreedDiscrimination?from=Main.TragicMulatto}}</ref>
===Folktales=== * ''[[Haunting of the Octoroon Mistress]]'', a ghost story featuring the institution of [[Plaçage#Quadroon balls|octoroon balls]].
=== Video games featuring "tragic mulatta" characters in pivotal roles === * ''[[Assassin's Creed: Liberation]]'', the first [[PlayStation Vita]] installment of the [[Assassin's Creed (series)|''Assassin's Creed'' series]], has the [[playable character]], Aveline, subvert the trope, according to ''[[Kotaku]]'' writer Evan Narcisse.<ref>{{cite web|title=I'm Surprised By How "Black" Assassin's Creed Liberation Feels|url=http://updates.kotaku.com/post/34760797518/im-surprised-by-how-black-assassins-creed|work=Kotaku|author=Evan Narcisse|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103102124/http://updates.kotaku.com/post/34760797518/im-surprised-by-how-black-assassins-creed|archivedate=2012-11-03|df=}}</ref> * Lincoln Clay of ''[[Mafia III]]'' fits this trope, being of (presumed) Dominican and Italian ancestry.
===Music=== * The 1973 song "[[Half-Breed (song)|Half-Breed]]" by [[Cher]] is a partially autobiographical account of the singer's mixed Cherokee and white ([[Armenian people|Armenian]]) ancestry.

{{refimprove|date=June 2015}} The '''Rock Paintings of Tsagaan Salaa''' are located in western [[Mongolia]]. Site is inside [[Altai Tavan Bogd National Park]] and was approved as part of a larger [[Petroglyphic Complexes of the Mongolian Altai]] World Heritage Site along with The Upper Tsagaan Gol Complex in 2011.{{cite web|author= |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1382 |title=Petroglyphic Complexes of the Mongolian Altai - UNESCO World Heritage Centre |publisher=Whc.unesco.org |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=24 February 2014}} ==Site description== Within an area of roughly 15 km2 reside approximately 10,000 figures on the southern side of the White River Valley. Dating from the Neolithic to the Bronze Age, this massive collection of pictorials primarily depicts livestock and big game both individual and in large herds.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/934/ Tsagaan salaa rock painting - UNESCO World Heritage Centre]
These rock paintings are rich not only in their numbers, but also in meanings, expressiveness, subject and compositions. They are important monuments of the art of the transition from ancient hunter-gatherer societies to livestock breeding and the beginning of the classic nomad economy in Mongolia.
==World Heritage status== This site was added to the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage]] Tentative List on August 1, 1996 in the Cultural category. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Wikivoyage|Altai Tavan Bogd National Park}} ==External links== *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/934/ Tsagaan salaa rock painting - UNESCO World Heritage Centre] Accessed 2009-03-02. {{Infobox UN resolution |number = 1757 |organ = SC |date = 30 May |year = 2007 |meeting = 5,685 |code = S/RES/1757 |document = https://undocs.org/S/RES/1757(2007) |for = 10 |abstention = 5 |against = 0 |subject = The situation in the Middle East |result = Adopted |image = |caption = }} '''[[United Nations Security Council Resolution]] 1757''' was unanimously adopted on 30 May 2007.
== Resolution == The United Nations Security Council today authorized the formation of an international tribunal to try suspects in the 2005 assassination of former Lebanese Prime Minister [[Rafiq Hariri]], although some members warned that the move could have serious political repercussions because the Council was exceeding its authority and interfering in Lebanese affairs.
By a vote of 10 in favour to none against, with 5 abstentions ( China, Indonesia, Qatar, Russian Federation and South Africa), the Security Council, acting under Chapter VII of the Charter, adopted resolution 1757 (2007) authorizing the creation of the Special Tribunal for Lebanon. It gives the Lebanese Government until 10 June “to notify the United Nations in writing that the legal requirements for entry into force have been complied with”, thus allowing Lebanese factions 10 days to reach an agreement internally before it goes into effect.
The requirements agreed between the world body and Lebanon last November are attached to the resolution, along with the Tribunal’s 30-article founding statute. The measure responds to a request from Lebanese Prime Minister Fouad Siniora, but the country’s Parliament has not approved the plan because speaker Nabih Berri has not convened the chamber.
Mindful of the Lebanese people’s demand that all those responsible for the 14 February 2005 terrorist bombing that killed the former Lebanese Premier and 22 others be identified and brought to justice, the Council also requested Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, coordinating with, when appropriate, the Lebanese Government, to take the steps and measures necessary to establish the Tribunal “in a timely manner” and to report to the Council within 90 days on the implementation of the resolution. The site of the tribunal would be decided in consultations with Beirut and the country that would host it. Expenses for the tribunal would be borne by United Nations Member States, unless Lebanon could take that responsibility.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2007/sc9029.doc.htm|title=Security Council authorizes establishment of special tribunal to try suspects in assassination of Rafiq Hariri|date=May 30, 2007|publisher=United Nations}}</ref>
